newsitem.title: GREECE: PRESS DIGEST - GREEK GENERAL NEWS- DEC 13.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - GREEK GENERAL NEWS- DEC 13.

text.p: Leading stories in the Greek general press:

--Ironically, state-run bank subsidiaries were found to be guilty of tax evasion, according to a list released by the finance ministry yesterday, part of efforts to combat tax evasion. The 481 cases, the ministry says, were involving in evading taxes estimated at 110 billion drachmas.

--The government appears to be without a uniform line on the issue of the continuing farmers' blockade, evidenced by Agirculture Minister Stephanos Tzoumakas's attack on farmers, while Prime Minister Costas Simitis says from the Hague that the protests will be dealt with "with discretion". Justice Minister Evangelos Yannopoulos meanwhile seemed to object to government spokesman Dimitris Reppas's statement that the courts should intervene in the 16-day blockade.
--Businessmen yesterday pleaded with farmers and government to find a way out of the impasse, saying the damage production, exports, tourism and the economy were facing was enormous.

--Additional measures - bolstering benefits to mothers of large families, housing ministries and management of hospitals, state procurements and state bodies' debts - are included in an amendment to the bill of public finances due to be submitted by Deputy Finance Minister Nikos Christodoulakis.

--Fines on tax evaders made public yesterday total 250 billion drachmas, with the olive oil and clothing industries in the 'top ten'.The olive oil industry is also involved in the illegal receipt of agricultural subsidies, comprising 33 of 36 cases.

--Deputy Interior Minister Tassos Mantellis unveils ambitious plans to overhaul public services, cut back on the papers needed for public services and institute phone orders for statutory certificates.
--Tzoumakas talks of 'crooks' and 'mafiosi' amongst the protesting farmers as farmers in Thessaly harden their stance and throw up new road blocks today.

--The environment, town planning and public works ministry is proceeding with plans to release the inner city districts of Exarhia, Strefi and Kolonaki from the grip of traffic congestion by extending existing pedestrian walkways and closing certain streets to traffic.
--Tonnes of meat, cheese and fresh food are in danger of spoiling the longer the blockade goes on: public health officials are on alert in the event spoiled food products reach market stalls.
--An amendment submitted to Parliament increases charges on alcoholic beverages by 25 percent --Maria Petrakis, Athens Newsroom +301 3311812-4
